headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Welcome to Sunoco Inc.'s Q4 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening, and welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call, where we will discuss the company's fourth quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory,
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening, and welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call, where we will discuss the company's fourth quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; and Clare McGrory, our Manager of Investor Relations. I'll start by making a few introductory comments, and then Brian will address business results and comment on our overall financial position and Fritz will provide an update on our Sunoco.
As part of today's call, I'd like to direct you to our website, www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted a number of presentation slides, which may provide a useful reference, as we progress through our remarks. I'd also like to refer you to the Safe Harbor statement referenced in Slide #2 of the Slide package and is included in this afternoon's earnings release.
Now let's begin. As you can see from Slide 3 and 4, we earned $13 million in net income, excluding special items or $0.11 per share. While I look at our performance in the fourth quarter, I see three things. First, the marketplace continue to be challenging, the weak demand and excess supply in our markets and the rising crude prices continue to put downward pressure on margins, especially in our retail business where it's more difficult to quickly pass through sharper higher raw material cost. 
On the refining and supply side, the northeast region experienced moderate improvement with higher market cracks, but rising crude prices also factored into refining's results. 
Second, we had additional work to do in the area of operational reliability, which negatively impacted results this quarter when processing units in our northeast refinery came down for unscheduled maintenance. Overall, our refining utilization for the quarter was 85%, well below our planned rate. Along with the crude margin capture, operational reliability remain our focus area for us this year. 
Third, we continue to make progress in executing our strategy. Sunoco Logistics Partners almost $400 million was invested for expansion capital during 2010. Additionally, we recently announced sale of the refinery to PBS which we expect to close in the first quarter, the purchase of 25 high-quality retail state in Upstate New York and a new long-term contracts to operate retail locations along New Jersey's Garden State Parkway, starting in 2011 and the Ohio turnpike beginning in 2012. We also continue to be successful in growing our distributor network. 
These various actions are part of a plan that aims for Sunoco to become the premiere provider of transportation fuel in our markets. Despite many challenges in 2010, I'm pleased to say Sunoco made progress against our strategic goal. We finished the year with $1.5 billion in cash, which provides us with considerable strategic flexibility. We also took steps to achieve growth in our retail and logistics businesses and to improve the overall competitiveness of our refinery. 
The work done last year set the stage for continued progress in 2011. This will only happen if we run our business effectively and in such a way that it can continue to grow even in difficult markets. We cannot count on helping the marketplace. It's our view that conditions in 2011 will be similar to what we saw in 2010. 
Our strategy to use our brand to pull fuel through our system depends on a tightly integrated team that executes well in each step of the value chain. In retail, we need to grow and protect the strong Sunoco brand, the customers have come to know and trust. This entails improving year-on-year sales for fuel and convenience items. By adding more locations who are providing a great customer experience at retail, we expect demand will pull product from our refineries and through the pipelines, terminals and branded retail network. I expect Sunoco Logistics to continue to integrate recent acquisitions while looking for additional growth opportunities inside and outside the traditional Sunoco footprint. 
The recent acquisition of the butane-blending business and the reversal and conversion of accrued pipeline to product service are good examples of the range of growth opportunities we're willing to consider. Our refineries sit and sidelined with a larger transportation of fuel markets in the world. If we can operate them safely, reliably and efficiently, we can be competitive in the marketplace. 
Our refining and supply segment remains focused on the fundamentals, improve margin capture, lower our breakeven cost per barrel and operate reliably and safely. 
The other part of our strategy, separating SunCoke Energy from Sunoco and preparing to operate independently remains a top priority. The recent acquisition of coal assets contiguous to our fuel operations increases our reserves, enable synergies with our existing mines and demonstrates how committed we are to preparing SunCoke for the next phase of growth as an independent entity. 
Fritz will talk about our preparations in more detail shortly, but I am pleased that we have reached a resettlement with Metal that resolved the lawsuit concerning coke pricing at the Jewell facility and we now can move forward with a separation of the business to unlock shareholder value. Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a pretax income of $121 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in the fourth quarter, which included $123 million pretax of
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a pretax income of $121 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in the fourth quarter, which included $123 million pretax of net of favorable special items. The special items were primarily associated with gains from the liquidation of crude oil and refined product inventories, a provision for asset write-downs attributable to the Eagle Point refinery and pension settlement losses and accruals for employee terminations and related cost in connection with the ongoing business improvement initiatives. 
We also recognize net benefit from taxes related to recurring Coke business tax credits, biofuels tax credits granted at year-end and other adjustments to recurring taxes, which occur the changes in estimates. 
We delivered another strong quarter in our logistics business and achieved our 2010 full year guidance for the Coke business. Market conditions were challenging in our retail and Refining and Supply business this quarter and operational issues in our refining facilities prevented us from taking advantage of the moderate sequential improvement that did occur in the northeast market. 
As you can see in Slide 4, refining and supply recorded a pretax loss of $17 million. While we are not satisfied in posting a loss in our refining and supply business, and we are working on the issues around operational reliability, we also can take a step back and recognize our year-over-year improvement in the business. We feel confident that the significant improvement is, to a large degree, the result of actions we have taken, including the closure of the Eagle Point refinery, the focus on reliability and optimization of our plants, refocusing our market strategy and last but not least, our initiatives around cost structure. 
Our focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues to yield results. Full year 2010 cash operating expenses, excluding fuel, utilities and discontinued operations, were approximately $185 million lower than 2009. Excluding the Coke business where we are adding costs as we grow and prepare for our separation, the improvement versus the prior year is approximately $240 million. This expense measurement basis of cash operating expenses ex fuel and utilities has been used internally to track our progress in reducing our controllable expenses was also part of our 2010 companywide bonus targets and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our cost to a competitive level. 
A year ago, we announced our decision to close the Eagle Point refinery. At that time, we communicated our goal to achieve breakeven cash flow in our Refining and Supply business even within a tough market environment similar to the one we were experiencing at that time. As a result of the actions we have taken for the full year 2010 as you can see on Slide 5, we generated positive EBIT that was in excess of our capital requirements for 2010 in the Refining and Supply business. This represents a tremendous improvement versus 2009 when the business experienced significant cash burn.
So while we continue to be pleased with our progress on many of our controllable aspects of our operations, we will continue to maintain focus on the fundamentals to ensure we are competitive with our assets and can make the most of the market opportunities that do present themselves. 
Regarding Q4 business unit results, I direct you to Slides 4 through 9. First, let's discuss the retail logistics and Coke segments, businesses which we continue to believe had the best prospects for growth. Our Retail Marketing logistics and Coke businesses earned $63 million pretax, $47 million after tax in the aggregate or in the quarter, as detailed on Slides 4 and 6. 
Retail Marketing earned $1 million pretax and $3 million after tax in the fourth quarter of 2010. Retail gasoline margins were significantly challenged, as crude prices and wholesale gasoline prices were on the rise throughout most of the quarter. 
While we experienced a challenging quarter, we earned $176 million pretax for the full year 2010, an improvement of $30 million versus the prior year. We do see volatility in this business quarter-to-quarter, but historical annual results proved that over time, this business delivers strong consistent results. We saw strong volume relative to the challenging quarter one year ago, gasoline and distillate volume is up by 1.8% and 7%, respectively on an open both year basis. Additionally, we made progress during the quarter in our retail growth strategy, including the acquisition of 25 sites in New York, newer extended agreements to extend precise on the Ohio turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and the Palisades Parkway and continued growth in the distributor network. At the end of the fourth quarter, more than 4,900 sides carried the Sunoco flag and this is the business we continue to target for growth.
Turning now to logistics, which earned $37 million pretax, $23 million after tax in the fourth quarter. The earnings in this business are almost entirely related to Sunoco's ownership interest in Sunoco Logistics, which continues to be a reliable source of earnings. The throughput and turning business has proven to be a ratable and growing business and is supplemented by crude oil market opportunities when contango market structures exist, as was the case in the third quarter and to a lesser extent, in the fourth quarter. 
The logistics business also had strong growth opportunities. Sunoco Logistics spent approximately $390 million in expansion capital during 2010, including both organic and acquisition projects. In 2011, Sunoco Logistics Partners projecting expansion capital to range from $100 million to $150 million excluding major acquisitions and project partners. Coker and $25 million pretax, $21 million after tax in Q4. The Coke business earned $132 million net income after tax for the full year, consistent with the earnings guidance previously provided. Relative to the third quarter, earnings were lower due to spot sales of coke in the third quarter and higher spending in the fourth quarter related to activities around growth and preparation to be a stand-alone business. Additionally, production issues at our Indiana Harbor plant and arbitration and legal cost impacted fourth quarter results. At the beginning of the year, we highlighted our expectation that we would be able to achieve breakeven cash flow in the Coke business. We are pleased to report that SunCoke generated EBITDA in excess of capital spending and also generated additional cash load to working capital in 2010. This is a significant accomplishment for the business, as it prepares to operate as a stand-alone business. 
Regarding the separation, now that the Jewell litigation is behind us, Sunoco intends to move forward with the planned separation of SunCoke in a two-step process. Later in the call, Fritz will address the settlement agreement regarding the Jewell plant. Our earned expedition for 2011 and '12 and provide an update on the growth outlook.
Now turning to Refining and Supply as shown on Slide 7. Refining and Supply at a loss of $17 million pretax or $8 million after tax in the fourth quarter of 2010, compared to a loss of $227 million pretax or $135 million after tax in the same quarter in 2009. We saw market conditions in the northeast system improve in the fourth quarter, as reflected in the market margins, but we experience operational issues, which hindered our performance. 
Our systemwide crude unit utilization rate was 85% for the fourth quarter, which is obviously much lower than the optimal rates given the margin environment. The northeast system was impacted by operational issues and the Toledo refinery utilization was also negatively impacted by crude oil, pipeline allocation limits. 
In the northeast, both refineries experienced mechanical issues late in the quarter for, which maintenance work continues into the first quarter of 2011. We expect to complete the maintenance activities in February and return to normal rates in March. As a result of this work, first quarter utilization for the northeast systems is expected to be similar to the first quarter of 2010. With respect to our Q4 margin realizations, refer you to Slide 8 and 9 for more detail on our refining system crude comp and product differentials versus our benchmark. 
As you can see on Slide 8, our systemwide Refining and Supply benchmark averaged 611 per barrel for the fourth quarter and margin capture was 78%. While market margins and margin capture rates were both significantly improved from the same quarter of last year, our margin capture was challenged by both rising crude prices and our own operational difficulties. Exceeding crude timing, which negatively impacted the capture rate for the second consecutive quarter, margin capture was 86%. Our operational issues resulted in lack of rateability, which also had a negative impact on our margin  capture in the midst of the current also pricing environment. 
Even with the difficulties experienced in the fourth quarter, we showed significant improvement in margin capture for the full year of 2010 versus 2009. Our improvements can be attributed to better reliability and a successful strategy matching operations to market opportunities. The improved reliability and utilization is both in the northeast and Toledo, as we were undergoing turnaround activity in Toledo during 2009. Overall as compared to last year, we benefited from higher overall distillate and ULSD production, as a percent of total production. Specifically in 2010, 36% of our net production was distillate versus 32% in 2009, with the offset being less production of the cheaper residual fuels. Our actions that supported the improvement include the closure of Eagle Point, adjustments in our crude slates and the operations of the new hydrotreater unit in Philadelphia. Within the distillate pool, we seized opportunities to upgrade more the distillate to ULSD when it was attractive to do so. Northeast ULSD differentials to reading are widened by $0.1.5 a gallon year-over-year. 
In summary, we still feel confident that we are executing on many of the factors within our control, both operational and how we are approaching the market. We have noted that there can't be market factors, which affect our margin capture rate in any given reporting period. Additionally, we recognize that reliability of our refineries is an essential component to strong performance and the fourth quarter is a demonstration of this. We will remain focused on the fundamentals, those elements within our control to drive strong performance in whatever environment exists. 
As previously noted, our first quarter utilization is expected to be similar to the fourth quarter due to maintenance work in our northeast system. Accordingly, we expect challenged refining and supply results again in the first quarter, given the resulting lower utilization level, along with still rising crude prices and relatively weaker northeast market conditions evident thus far. 
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of December. In conjunction with that, I'll direct you to Slide 10 and 11. From a funds flow perspective, our fourth quarter net cash flow before debt activity at at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics was a source of approximately $360 million. We ended the quarter with cash exceeding debt by approximately $180 million, excluding SXL. This represents a swing of $1.4 billion from the prior year end when the Sunoco parent was carrying $1.2 billion of net debt. The cash increase in the quarter was driven by working capital movements, as we liquidated inventories related to our Eagle Point refinery, which was shut down in late 2009. We ended the quarter with a net debt to capital ratio of negative 6% at the Sunoco level, excluding SXL. 
At December 31, we had $1.5 billion of cash and approximately $1.5 billion of available committed borrowing capacity. As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position and liquidity continues to be very strong. As seen on Slide 12, our capital spend for 2010, excluding Sunoco Logistics Partners, was $614 million, which included $223 million for Refining and Supply without the gross spending for the plan. We were successful in managing capital for this business and reduced our total spread by approximately $75 million versus our guidance at the beginning of the year. This reduction has been achieved, primarily due to cost efficiencies in projects, as well as some deferred projects, which had no impact on safe and reliable operations. We continue to focus on running safe and reliable operations, but we will also continue to limit the discretionary capital that is put into this business. 
As it relates to capital spending and expectations for Refining and Supply in 2011, we are currently in discussions with the appropriate government environmental authorities about the requirements of the 2006 consent decree as it applies to the markets of refinery. As we have previously reported, we have completed projects at the Philadelphia and Toledo refineries under a 2006 consent decree. We had expected to make additional capital outlays of approximately $200 million at the Marcus Hook focus refinery under the same consent decree by June 30, 2013. We are hopeful that in no time these recent discussions will include an extension of the required timeframe for these capital outlays, thus reducing our capital outlays in 2011 and 2012. This will allow us additional time to explore options that will lower the cost of the total project. If these discussions are successful and subject to the closing of the Toledo refinery sale, we expect 2011 capital spending and Refining and Supply business to range from $135 million to $145 million, down from 2010 and below DD&A. 
While we are closely managing our capital spend in the Refining and Supply business, we are targeting our Coke Logistics and Retail businesses for growth opportunities. Our 2011 capital guidance, as shown on Slide 12, includes approximately $165 million to finish the SunCoke Middletown plant, which is expected to be running late in the second half of 2011. We also showed logistics capital spend, including maintenance capital in the range of $145 million to $195 million, which is expected to be funded by Sunoco Logistics Partners and excludes any potential major acquisitions and project MARINER spend. 
Lastly, we've continued to pursue growth opportunities in our Retail business. These will be opportunistic and thus are not included in our capital guidance at this time.
As we look forward to 2011, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses, as well as ride out the challenging and volatile refining environment. 
A final balance sheet note related to inventory. At December 31, the current replacement cost of all inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $3.1 billion. Now I'll turn the call over to Fritz Henderson who will provide an update on the SunCoke business.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good evening. First as noted in our press release earlier this week, we did reach a settlement with regard to the lawsuit filed by our concerning our coke pricing from our Jewell facility. The settlement agreement is effective January 1 thi
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good evening. First as noted in our press release earlier this week, we did reach a settlement with regard to the lawsuit filed by our concerning our coke pricing from our Jewell facility. The settlement agreement is effective January 1 this year 2011 and includes the following terms. First, the renegotiation of the Jewell coke contract, including the elimination of what was called the Jewell coal cut multiplier and the increase in the fees at Jewell. The pricing of Jewell coal will be based upon the third-party coal price at SunCoke's Haverhill facility. Second, a renegotiation and increase in the fees paid under the Haverhill agreement. Third, the Take-or-Pay basis of both Jewell and Haverhill agreements with our mail will be extended to 2020. This extension provides SunCoke a guarantee outlet for this coke production through 2028. Both of these contracts were previously structured to convert to the basis of our requirement effective 2012 so we extended the Take-or-Pay through 2020. 
Finally, in addition to resolving the Jewell litigation earlier this week, we also negotiated a settlement of arbitration claims related to our supply of coke from our Indiana Harbor site. Cost associated with the settlement was largely accrued in the fourth quarter. Combined with the Jewell settlement, we have now resolved all of our existing material and commercial disputes with along with a focus of building a productive dialogue in partnership with our largest customer, including possible extension of the Indiana Harbor contract that expires in 2013. The Indiana Harbor contract is to date the only contract that we have not covered by longer-term Take-or-Pay arrangements. We are pleased to put these matters behind us. We continue to move forward with our plans to separate the business and unlock shareholder value.
On the operating side of the business, reflecting both operating and capacity issues at our Indiana Harbor facility, we did not deliver to our contractual minimum to 2010. This is the only facility were we've missed our minimum since 2010. As the coke was not required, there were no shortfall penalties payable by SunCoke. 
With regard to 2011, while we are aggressively pursuing other reliability repairs and throughput initiatives, we do not expect to be able to restore volumes to the contractual minimum to the Indiana Harbor. And as such, we are working with our customer to identify possible other supply sources while we implement operating improvements in our own facilities. 
Let me take a moment to discuss earnings guidance, turning to Slide 14. In 2011, SunCoke Energy is expected to earn EBITDA in range of $165 million to $200 million, based upon our average contracted coal purchase price for 2011 of approximately $165 per ton. As compared to 2010 actual results, earnings of 2011 will be lower due to the rise of the terms of the Jewell coke contract and higher operating cost related to relocation of the business from Knoxville to Chicago and operation as a stand-alone company, partially offset by higher coke market prices and higher production related to a full year granted to the operations and the expected startup of our Middletown operations. 
In 2012, with a full year of Middletown operations and increased coal production from our expansion, we expect EBITDA to range from $280 million to $320 million. This assumes a coal price of approximately $175 per ton. Coal purchases have not yet been contracted for 2012. They wouldn't expect them to be contracted forward until late in 2011, but $175 these are well below where we see coal prices in the spot markets today. 
The net income guidance shown on the chart flows from the EBITDA levels, but does not include any interest expense associated with a yet to be determined capital structure for SunCoke.
As Slide 15 reflects, we continue to work towards preparing SunCoke for a successful operation as a standalone entity, including preparing for the relocation of our headquarters to Chicago and hiring key leadership. 
While we prepare for the separation of the SunCoke business, we also continue to actively pursue opportunities for new projects, both in the U.S. and internationally. As we saw once again in the most recent steel downturn, long term Take-or-Pay agreements provided strong measure of stability in our future cash flows, where all of our customers respecting their commitments to this most recent period for example. Looking forward, beyond the stable base of our existing contracts, we continue to see a number of growth opportunities, in both coke and in coal specifically. In the U.S., we're seeing demand for initial coke supply from multiple customers. When combined with our desire to introduce a small amount of merchant capacity into our coke battery fleet, we see an opportunity to build at least one more U.S. coke plant with a potential to be larger than our traditional coking batteries. And here, I'm referring to our batteries at Haverhill 1 and 2, as well as our Granite City facility . These facilities typically have 250 and 600,000 tons per year capacity. 
In coal, we're expanding capacity in our existing Jewell mythology for Goldman exceeding production for 1.2 million ton per year to approximately 1.7 million tons per year by the end of 2012. On an annualized basis. We also riddled the completed acquisition of your looking goal, which will take our production to an estimated 2 million tons per year by the end of 2012. Reflecting the elimination of the Jewell multiplier but also the expansion of our call pressure to more price sensitivity at cold is expected to be plus or minus $20 million of the pretax earnings for every $10 per ton moving in coal prices again in a run rate basis by the end of 2012.
Internationally, we see opportunities to expand and grow our footprint was likely for the ventures and our alliances in India, Eastern Europe, Brazil and China, something that we are prioritizing in 2011. Let me turn it back to lead to close the call.

First on the perspective filing, due to the SEC regulations and under the advice of counsel, it would not be appropriate to comment beyond what we've said in the script, namely that we are proceeding with this operation and the separation will be a two-step process. Would regard to your second question around the timing, as we go through the separation process, certain events are under our control and certain events are. Part of the separation process that will involve going through certain SEC filings and related processes and those processes as an example are not fully in our control. As you know, we settled the Arsenal matter and we are moving forward as expeditiously as possible and we plan to separate the separation as it is possible and clearly, would like to get the step, first of separation on as soon as possible.

componenttext: Mark, it's Brian here. A couple of things. I think clearly the cash generation today is a lot better than it's been, but it's not particularly exciting. That said, we're working on a number of things to reduce costs, capture more margin, bring down the capital, run the assets better and therefore, by definition, generate more cash, as we go through the cycle. As you think about that inventory, don't forget to do the math on the associated taxes, as well as the other side of the balance sheet, which is the payable side of those inventories, so make sure you kind of look on both side of the balance sheet and you think through some of the tax consequences there. And we are well aware of those numbers and calculations and we're focused on getting the refineries running better and throwing out more cash and I think last year, we made a step function improvement and we've got more work to do.

componenttext: Yes, I guess what I would say is that we already have a lot of toll business and the toll business that we are going into is going to be relatively similar to toll business we've had before. The stations that have been in the New York area retail stations that have the opportunity for us to improve their operation significantly from where they are today, so that's where the value creation comes from and we would expect them to be in line with the rest of our lease-type operations. And then on the other piece of that, which doesn't show up on the Sunoco Inc. side is that we think there will be some opportunities to get some slight incremental income on the SXL side. It doesn't show up directly, but it will show up indirectly. And then about 75-ish I think distributor locations and we would expect them to perform very similarly to the other rest of the distributor cost of trade.

If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I would now like to turn the call over to Lynn Elsenhans, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good evening. And welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call, where we will be discussing the company's fourth quarter earnings as we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer, Fritz Henderson
componenttext:
Thank you and good evening. And welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call, where we will be discussing the company's fourth quarter earnings as we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer, Fritz Henderson, who will be the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of SunCoke Energy upon separation and Clare McGrory, our Manager of Investor Relations.
I'll start with a few introductory comments and then Brian will address business results and comment on our overall financial position and Fritz will provide an update on the Sunoco business. As part of today's call, Id like to direct you to our website, www.sunocoinc.com where we have posted a number of presentation slides which may provide a useful reference as we progress through our remarks.
Id also like to refer you to the Safe Harbor Statement referenced in slide number two of the slide package and thats included in this afternoon's earnings release. Now let's begin.
As you can see from slides three and four, we earned $13 million in net income, excluding special items or a $.011 per share. When I look at our performance in the fourth quarter, I see three things.
First, the marketplace continued to be challenging, the weak demand and excess supply in our markets and the rising crude prices continue to put downward pressure on margins, especially in our retail business where it's more difficult to quickly tax through sharper, higher raw material costs. On our refining and supply side, the Northeast region experienced moderate improvement with higher market cracks, but rise in crude prices also factored into refinings results.
Second, we have additional work to do in the area of operational reliability, which negatively impacted results this quarter, when processing units in our Northeast refineries came down for unscheduled maintenance. Overall, refining unit utilization for the quarter was 85%, well below our planned rate. Along with improved margin capture, operational reliability remain a focus area for us this year.
Third, we continue to make progress in executing our strategy. In Sunoco, logistics partners almost 400 million were invested for expansion capital during 2010. Additionally, we recently announced sale of the Toledo refinery to PBF, which we expect to close in the first quarter, the purchase of 25 high quality retail sites in upstate New York and new long-term contracts to operate retail locations along New Jersey's Garden State Parkway, starting in 2011 and the Ohio Turnpike beginning in 2012.
We also continue to be successful in growing our distributor network. These various actions are part of a plan that aim for Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in our markets. Despite many challenges in 2010, I'm pleased to say Sunoco made progress against our strategic goals.
We finished the year with $1.5 billion in cash, which provides us with considerable strategic flexibility. We also took steps to achieve growth in our retail and logistics businesses and to improve the overall competitiveness of our refinery.
The work done last year sets the stage for continued progress in 2011. This will only happen if we run our business effectively and in such a way that it can continue to grow even in difficult markets. We cannot count on help for the marketplace. Its our view that condition in 2011 will be similar to what we saw in 2010.
Our strategy to use our brands to pull fuel through our system depends on a tightly integrated team that executes well at each step of the value chain. And retail, we need to grow and protect the strong Sunoco brands that customers have come to know and trust. This entails improving year on year sales from fuel and convenience items.
By adding more locations and providing a great customer experience at retail, we expect demand will pull product from our refineries and through the pipeline's terminals and branded retail network. I expect Sunoco logistics to continue to integrate recent acquisitions while looking for additional growth opportunities inside and outside the traditional Sunoco footprint.
The recent acquisition of the butane blending business and the reversal and conversion of accrued pipeline to product service are good examples of the range of growth opportunities we're willing to consider. Our refineries sit inside one of the largest transportation fuel markets in the world. If we can operate them safely, reliably and efficiently, we can be competitive in the marketplace.
Our refining and supply segment remains focused on the fundamentals. Improved market capture, lower break-even cost per barrel, and operate reliably and safely. The other part of our strategy, separating Sunoco's energy from Sunoco and preparing to operate independently remained the top priority.
The recent acquisition of coal assets contiguous to our dual operation increases our reserves, enables synergies with our existing line and demonstrates how committed we are to preparing SunCoke for its next phase of growth as an independent entity. First we'll talk about our separations in more detail shortly, but I am pleased that we have reached a settlement with ArcelorMittal that resolves the lawsuit concerning Coke pricing at the Jewell facility, and we now can move forward with the separation of the business to unlock shareholder value. Now, I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a pretax income of $121 million, attributable to Sunoco shareholders in the fourth quarter, which included $123 million pretax n
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a pretax income of $121 million, attributable to Sunoco shareholders in the fourth quarter, which included $123 million pretax net of favorable special items.
The special items were primarily associated with gains from the liquidation of crude oil and refine product inventories, our provision for asset write-downs attributable to the Eagle Point refinery and pension settlement losses and accruals for employee terminations and related costs in connection with the ongoing business improvement initiative.
We also recognize net benefit from taxes related to recurring Coke business tax credits, biofuels tax credits granted at year end and other adjustments to recurring taxes that would occur with changes and estimates. We delivered another strong quarter in our logistics business and achieved our 2010 full year guidance for the Coke business.
Market conditions were challenging in our retail and refining and supply business this quarter, and operational issues at our refining facilities prevented us from taking advantage of the moderate sequential improvement that did occur in the Northeast market.
As you can see in slide four, refining and supply recorded a pretax loss of $17 million. While we are not satisfying posting a loss in our refining and supply business and we are working on the issues around operational reliability, we also can take a step back and recognize our year-over-year improvement in the business.
We feel confident that the significant improvement is to a large degree the result of actions we have taken, including the closure of the Eagle Point refinery, the focus on reliability and optimization of our plants, refocusing our market strategy and last, but not least, our initiatives around cost structure.
Our focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues to yield results. Full year 2010 cash operating expenses excluding fuel, utilities and discontinued operations were approximately $185 million lower than 2009. Excluding the Coke business, where we are adding costs as we grow and prepare for separation, the improvement versus the prior year is approximately $240 million.
This expense measurement, the basis of cash operating expenses, ex fuel and utilities has been used internally to track our progress and reducing our controllable expenses, was also part of our 2010 companywide bonus targets and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our costs to a competitive level.
A year ago, we announced our decision to close the Eagle Point refinery. At that time, we communicated our goal to achieve break-even cash flow in our refining and supply business, even within a tough market environment, similar to the one we were experiencing at the time.
As a result of the actions we have taken, for the full year 2010, as you can see on slide five, we generated positive EBITDA that was in excess of our capital requirements for 2010 in the refining and supply business. This represents a tremendous improvement versus 2009 when the business experienced significant cash burn.
While we continue to be pleased with our progress in many of the controllable aspects of our operations, we will continue to maintain focus on the fundamentals to ensure we are competitive with our assets and can make the most of the market opportunities that do present themselves.
Regarding Q4 business unit results, I direct you to slides four through nine. First, lets discuss the retail, logistics and Coke segments. Businesses which we continued to believe had the best prospects for growth are retail marketing, logistics and Coke businesses earn $63 million pretax, $47 million after tax in the aggregate during the quarter as detailed on slides four and six.
Retail marketing earned $1 million pretax and $3 million after tax in the fourth quarter 2010. Retail gasoline margins were significantly challenged as crude prices and wholesale gasoline prices were on the rise throughout most of the quarter. While we experienced a challenging quarter, we earned $176 million pretax for the full year 2010, an improvement of $30 million versus the prior year.
We do see volatility in this business quarter to quarter, but historical annual results prove that over time, this business delivers strong, consistent results. We saw strong volumes relative to the challenging quarter one year ago. Gasoline and distillate volumes were up by 1.8% and 7% respectively on an open book year basis.
Additionally, we made progress during the quarter in our retail growth strategy, including the acquisition of 25 sites in New York, newer extended agreements to operate sites on the Ohio Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway, and the [Palla States] Parkway, and continued growth in the distributor network. At the end of the fourth quarter, more than 4,900 sites carried the Sunoco flag, and this is a business we continue to target for growth.
Turning now to logistics which earned $37 million pretax, $23 million after tax in the fourth quarter. Earnings in this business are almost entirely related to Sunocos ownership interest in Sunoco logistics, which continues to be a reliable source of earnings.
The throughput in [tourmaline] business has proven to be a ratable and growing business and is supplemented by crude oil market opportunities when [contangle] market structures exist, as was the case in the third quarter and to a lesser extent in the fourth quarter. The logistics business also has strong growth opportunities.
Sunoco Logistics spent approximately $390 million in expansion capital during 2010 including both organic and acquisition projects. In 2011, Sunoco Logistics Partner projecting expansion capital to range from $100 million to $150 million, excluding major acquisitions and project Mariner.
Coke earned $25 million pretax, $21 million after tax in Q4. The Coke business earned $132 million net income after tax for the full year, consistent with the earnings guidance previously provided. Relative to the third quarter, earnings were lower due to spot sales of Coke in the third quarter and higher spending in the fourth quarter related to activities around growth and preparation to be a standalone business.
Additionally, production issues at our Indiana Harbor plant and arbitration and legal costs impacted fourth quarter results. At the beginning of the year, we highlighted our expectation that we would be able to achieve break-even cash flow in the Coke business. We are pleased to report that SunCoke generated EBITDA in excess of capital spending and also generated additional cash flow through working capital in 2010.
This is a significant accomplishment for the business as it prepares to operate as a standalone business. Regarding the separation, now that the Jewell litigation is behind us, Sunoco intends to move forward with the planned separation of SunCoke in a two-step process. Later in the call, Fritz will address the settlement agreement regarding the Jewell plant outlined earning expectations for 2011 and '12 and provide an update on the growth outlook.
Now, turning to refining and supply, as shown on slide seven, refining and supply had a loss of $17 million pretax, or $8 million after tax in the fourth quarter of 2010, compared to a loss of $227 million pretax, or $135 million after tax in the same quarter 2009. We saw market conditions in the Northeast system improve in the fourth quarter as reflected in the market margins, but we experienced operational issues which hindered our performance.
Our system-wide crude unit utilization rate was 85% for the fourth quarter, which is obviously much lower than the optimal rates given the margin environment. The Northeast system was impacted by operational issues and the Toledo refinery utilization was also negatively impacted by crude oil, pipeline allocation limits.
In the Northeast, both refineries experienced mechanical issues late in the quarter for which maintenance work continues into the first quarter of 2011. We expect to complete the maintenance activities in February and return to normal rates in March. As a result of this work, first quarter utilizations for the Northeast system is expected to be similar to the fourth quarter of 2010.
With respect to our Q4 margin realizations, I refer you to slides eight and nine for more detail on a refining system crude cost and product differentials versus our benchmark. As you can see on slide eight, our system-wide refining and supply benchmark averaged 611 per barrel for the fourth quarter and margin capture was 78%.
While market margins and market capture rates were both significantly improved from the same quarter of last year, our margin capture was challenged by both rising crude prices and our own operational difficulties. Excluding crude timing, which negatively impacted the capture rate for the second consecutive quarter, margin capture was 86%.
Our operational issues resulted in lack of ratability, which also had a negative impact on our margin capture in the midst of the current volatile price environment. Even with the difficulties experienced in the fourth quarter, we showed significant improvement in margin capture for the full year 2010 versus 2009.
Improvements can be attributed to better reliability and a successful strategy matching operations to market opportunities. The improved reliability and utilization is both in the Northeast and Toledo, as we were undergoing turnaround activity in Toledo during late 2009.
Overall, as compared to last year, we benefited from higher overall distillate and ULSD production as a percent of total production. Specifically, in 2010, 36% of our net production was distillate versus 32% 2009, with the offset being less production of the cheaper residual fuels.
Our actions that supported the improvement include the closure of Eagle Point, adjustments in our crude slates, and the operations of the new hydrotreater unit in Philadelphia. Within the distillate pool, we seized opportunities to upgrade more of the distillate to ULSD when it was attractive to do so. Northeast ULSD differentials to heating oil widened by $1.5 a gallon year-over-year.
In summary, we still feel confident that we are executing on many of the factors within our control, both operational and how we are approaching the market. We have noted that there can be market factors which affect our margin capture rate in any given reporting period. Additionally, we recognize that reliability of our refineries is an essential component to strong performance and the fourth quarter is a demonstration of this.
We will remain focused on the fundamentals, those elements within our control that drive strong performance in whatever environment exist. As previously noted, our first quarter utilization is expected to be similar to the fourth quarter due to maintenance work in our Northeast system.
Accordingly, we expect challenged refining and supply results again in the first quarter, given the resulting lower utilization level, along with still-arising crude prices and relatively weaker Northeast market conditions evident thus far. Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of December. In conjunction with that, I'll direct you to slides 10 and 11.
From a funds flow perspective, our fourth quarter net cash flow before debt at Sunoco excluding Sunoco Logistics was a source of approximately $360 million. We ended the quarter with cash exceeding debt by approximately $180 million, excluding SXL. This represents a swing of $1.4 billion from the prior year end, when the Sunoco parent was carrying 1.2 billion of net debt.
The cash increase in the quarter was driven by working capital movements as we liquidated inventories related to our Eagle Point refinery, which was shut down in late 2009. We ended the quarter with a net debt to capital ratio of negative 6% at the Sunoco level excluding SXL.
At December 31, we had $1.5 billion of cash and approximately $1.5 billion of available committed borrowing capacity. As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position and liquidity continues to be very strong. As seen on slide 12, our capital spend for 2010 excluding Sunoco Logistics Partners was $614 million, which included $223 million for refining and supply, without the gross spending for the Fulton biofuels plant.
We were successful in managing capital for this business and reduced our total spend by approximately 75 million versus our guidance at the beginning of the year. This reduction has been achieved, primarily due to cost efficiencies in projects, as well as some deferred projects which have no impact on safe and reliable operations. We continue to focus on running safe and reliable operations, but we will also continue to limit the discretionary capital that is put into this business.
As it relates to capital spending expectations for refining and supply in 2011, we are currently in discussions with the appropriate government environmental authorities about the requirements of the 2006 consent decree as it applies to the markets for refinery. As we have previously reported, we have completed projects at the Philadelphia and Toledo refineries under a 2006 consent decree.
We have expected to make additional capital outlays of approximately $200 million as the markets of refinery under the same consent degree by June 30, 2013. We are hopeful that an outcome of these recent discussions will include an extension of the required timeframe for these capital outlays, thus reducing our capital outlays in 2011 and 2012.
This will allow us additional time to explore our options that will lower the costs of the total project. If these discussions are successful and subject to the closing of the Toledo refinery sale, we expect 2011 capital spending and refining and supply business to range from $135 million to $145 million, down from 2010 and below DD&A.
Where we are closely managing our capital spend in the refining and supply business, we are targeting our Coke logistics and retail business for growth opportunities. Our 2011 capital guidance as shown on slide 12 includes approximately $165 million to finish the SunCoke Middletown plant, which is expected to be running late in the second half of 2011.
We also show logistics capital spend including maintenance capital in the range of 145 million to 195 million, which is expected to be funded by Sunoco Logistics Partners and excludes any potential major acquisitions and Project Mariner spend.
Lastly, we continue to pursue growth opportunities in our retail business. These will be opportunitistic and thus are not included in our capital guidance at this time.
As we look forward to 2011, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses, as well as ride out the challenging the volatile of refining environment, our final balance sheet note related to inventory. At December 31, the current replacement cost of all inventories devalued at LIFO exceed their carrying value by $3.1 billion.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Fritz Henderson, who will provide an update on the SunCoke business.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good evening. First, as noted in our press release earlier this week, we did reach a settlement with regard to the lawsuit filed by ArcelorMittal concerning Coke pricing from our Jewell facility. The settlement agreement is effective Januar
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good evening. First, as noted in our press release earlier this week, we did reach a settlement with regard to the lawsuit filed by ArcelorMittal concerning Coke pricing from our Jewell facility. The settlement agreement is effective January 1 of this year, 2011 and includes the following terms.
First, renegotiation of the Jewell Coke contract, including the elimination of what was called the Jewell coal cost multiplier and the increase in the fees at Jewell. The pricing of Jewell coal will be based upon the third party coal price at SunCoke's Haverhill facility.
Second, renegotiation and increase in the fees paid under the Haverhill agreement. Third, the take or pay basis of the Jewell, of both Jewell and Haverhill agreements with ArcelorMittal will be extended through 2020. This extension provides SunCoke a guarantee outlet for this coke production through 2020 and both of these contracts were previously structured to convert to the basis of ArcelorMittals U.S. requirement effective October 2012.
So we extended the take or pay through 2020. Finally, and in addition to resolving the Jewell litigation, earlier this week, we also negotiated a settlement of arbitration claims related to our supply of Coke to ArcelorMittal from our Indiana Harbor site. Costs associated with the settlement were largely accrued in the fourth quarter.
Combined with the Jewell settlement, we have now resolved all of our existing material commercial disputes with ArcelorMitall. Our line is to focus on building a productive dialogue in partnership with our largest customer, including possible extension at the Indiana Harbor contract that expires in 2013.
The Indiana Harbor contract is today the only contract that we have not covered by longer-term take or pay rate. We're pleased to put these matters behind us, so we can continue to move forward with our plans to separate the business and unlock shareholder value.
On the operating side of the business, reflecting both operating and capacity issues that are at the Indiana Harbor facility, we did not deliver to our contractual minimum to 2010. This is the only facility where we missed our minimums in 2010. As the Coke was not required however, there were no shortfall penalties payable by SunCoke.
With regard to 2011, while we're aggressively pursuing other reliability repairs and throughput initiatives, we do not expect to be able to restore volumes to the contractual minimum in the Indiana Harbor and as such, we're working with our customer to identify possible other supply sources while we implement operating improvements in our own facilities.
Let me take a moment to discuss earnings guidance and turn you to slide 14. In 2011, SunCoke energy is expected to turn EBITDA in the range of $165 million to $200 million, based upon our average contracted coal purchase price for 2011 of approximately $165 per ton.
As compared to 2010 actual results, earnings in 2011 will be lower due to the revised terms of the Jewell Coke contract and higher operating costs related to relocation of the business from Knoxville to Chicago and operation as a standalone company, partially offset by higher coke market prices and higher production related to a full year of Grand City operations and the expected startup of our Middletown operations.
In 2012, with a full year of Middletown operations and increased coal production from our expansion, we expect EBITDA to range from $280 million to $320 million. This assumes coal price of approximately $175 per ton.
Coal purchases have not yet been contracted for 2012. We wouldn't expect them to be contracted for until late in 2011, but at $175, these are well below where we see coal prices in the spot markets today. The net income guidance as shown on the chart flows from EBITDA levels, but does not include any interest expense associated with the yet to be determined capital structure for SunCoke.
As slide 15 reflects, we continue to work towards preparing SunCoke for successful operation as a standalone entity, including preparing for the relocation of our headquarters to Chicago and hiring key leadership. While we prepare for the separation of the SunCoke business, we also continue to actively pursue opportunities for new projects, both in the U.S. and internationally.
As we saw once again in the most recent steel downturn, long-term take or pay agreements provide a strong measure of stability in our future cash flows, with all of our customers respecting their commitments through this most recent period, for example. Looking forward, beyond the stable base of our existing contracts, we continue to see a number of growth opportunities in both Coke and in coal specifically.
In the U.S., we're seeing demand for additional Coke supply from multiple customers. When combined with our desire to introduce a small amount of merchant capacity into our Coke battery fleet, we see an opportunity to build at least one more U.S. Coke plant with the potential to be larger than our traditional Coking batteries, and here I'm referring to our batteries in Haverhill one and two as well as Grand City facility and these facilities typically have between 550 and 600,000 tons per year capacity.
And coal were expanding capacity in our existing Jewell metallurgical coal mine increasing production for 1.2 million tons per year to approximately 1.7 million tons per year by the end of 2012 on an annualized basis. Excuse me. We also recently completed the acquisition of Harold Keene Coal, which will take our production to an estimated 2 million tons per year by the end of 2012.
Reflecting the elimination of the jewel multiplier, but also the expansion of our coal production, our price sensitivity to coal is expected to be plus or minus $20 million in pretax earnings, for every $10 per ton movement in coal prices again, on a running rate basis by the end of 2012. Internationally, we see opportunities to expand and grow our footprint, most likely through ventures and/or alliances in India, Eastern Europe, Brazil and China, something we are prioritizing in 2011.
Let me turn it back to Lynn to close the call.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fritz. So in closing, delivering value to shareholders, we will continue to execute a strategy that positions Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in our market. This strategy includes pursuing growth in retail and logisti
componenttext:
Thanks, Fritz. So in closing, delivering value to shareholders, we will continue to execute a strategy that positions Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in our market. This strategy includes pursuing growth in retail and logistics, for potential returns are highest, while continuing to run our manufacturing facility safely, reliably, and efficiently.
With that, I'll ask the moderator to open the line to any questions you may have.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Paul Cheng. Your line is open.
componenttext: Thank you. (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Paul Cheng. Your line is open.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hey guys. Number of hopefully quick question, on the separation, I think, previous self imposed timeline is mid of the year, we have the lawsuit that seems like we may have some delay where are we standing in the process, when we expect the separation goi
componenttext: Hey guys. Number of hopefully quick question, on the separation, I think, previous self imposed timeline is mid of the year, we have the lawsuit that seems like we may have some delay where are we standing in the process, when we expect the separation going to happen and when could we expect the form 10 or S1 will be filed?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Paul, I'll answer your question in two parts. First, on the, the perspective filing, due to SEC regulations and under the advice of counsel, it would not be appropriate to comment beyond what weve said in the script, namely that we are proceeding with
componenttext:
Paul, I'll answer your question in two parts. First, on the, the perspective filing, due to SEC regulations and under the advice of counsel, it would not be appropriate to comment beyond what weve said in the script, namely that we are proceeding with the separation and the separation will be a two-step process.
With regard to your second question around the timing, you know, as we go through the separation process, certain events are under our control and certain events aren't. Part of the separation process will involve going through a certain SEC filings and related processes and those processes as an example are not fully in our control.
As you noted, weve settled the Arcelor matter and we're moving forward as expeditiously as possible. And we plan to effect the separation as soon as practicable and clearly, we would like to get the step -- first step of separation done as soon as possible.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Our next question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Thank you. Our next question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good evening, guys. Two questions, if I could. Could you discuss the capital structure of SunCoke, we see that in the S1. And with any incremental cash upstream to Sun from SunCoke leverage, and I appreciate if you can't get a number now for the reasons t
componenttext: Good evening, guys. Two questions, if I could. Could you discuss the capital structure of SunCoke, we see that in the S1. And with any incremental cash upstream to Sun from SunCoke leverage, and I appreciate if you can't get a number now for the reasons that you just discussed. Plus your current high and growing cash position, plus Eagle point inventories, I presume, are another incremental $100 million. Do you see growth opportunities in that size for Sun parent, which is somewhere north of $2 billion, or where are your views in returning, potentially returning capital to shareholders? And then I have a follow-up, please.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. So, on the first question around capital structure, as I'm sure you picked up from Paul, we won't really have much more to say on this call. With regard to the cash, you know, clearly the balance sheet's in a pretty good position and is dramat
componenttext: Sure, Evan. So, on the first question around capital structure, as I'm sure you picked up from Paul, we won't really have much more to say on this call. With regard to the cash, you know, clearly the balance sheet's in a pretty good position and is dramatically improved from where it was a year ago. That said, the refining environment continues to be challenging, and so the cash balance gives us flexibility there. We continue to want to grow in SXL and retail and see some uses of the cash to grow those businesses and then we also see some debt reduction as weve talked about in the past. And lastly, with this amount of cash, we have a lot of strategic flexibility and optionality.

Sorry, Fritz, to belabor this point but -- so basically the previous guidance obviously has come down with a 60 million impact from the settlement. But if I look at the sensitivity you had given us previously on the -- the fact you've got from 125 to 175 coal assumption, looks like something else has changed there because net-net, the EBITDA looks like it is a little bit light. Can you kind of walk us through those moving parts? And I also have a follow-up, please.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yeah. There is two issues. There's actually three. Two of which are the most significant. One is we have built the prior guidance didn't include standalone costs in the forecast. This forecast does include all the standalone costs associated with running
componenttext:
Yeah. There is two issues. There's actually three. Two of which are the most significant. One is we have built the prior guidance didn't include standalone costs in the forecast. This forecast does include all the standalone costs associated with running the business separately.
The second piece, we have -- we have seen increases in coal production costs, which we have built into this revised guidance. So you're right in saying the, the restructured Arcelor contract is unfavorable relative to prior guidance. Higher coal prices is favorable, but the two pieces missing are, one, we need to update and we did update the coal production costs. And second, we've built in all the standalone costs associated with running the business publicly.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, as I said, I'll answer the second question first. We've talked about, when I went through the presentation. Basically, when we look at the sensitivity to coal prices, once you get to 2 million units, excuse me, 2 million tons, the sensitivity
componenttext: Okay. Well, as I said, I'll answer the second question first. We've talked about, when I went through the presentation. Basically, when we look at the sensitivity to coal prices, once you get to 2 million units, excuse me, 2 million tons, the sensitivity is 2 million times $10. So, you know, it's plus or minus 20 million of profit or pretax profit for every $10 movement in pricing coal because you would hold at that point your production costs constant, what youre doing is variance in the price.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: All right. So your first question on where coal prices are today, first of all, not a lot is trading in the spot market. The primary source of spot coal, met coal in the world is Australia, and Australia's being hit by both the flood impact, as well as no
componenttext:
All right. So your first question on where coal prices are today, first of all, not a lot is trading in the spot market. The primary source of spot coal, met coal in the world is Australia, and Australia's being hit by both the flood impact, as well as now the cyclone impact. If you had to go out and purchase spot met coal today, it's in our best judgment is it's well above $200 a ton today, and it's really not readily available, given what's happened.
Most coal is contracted for on a long-term basis, though. But it's pretty clear that combination of continued demand growth in China, continued opportunity -- continued demand growth in India for met coal, combined with a reasonable outlook in the U.S. and in Brazil, I mean, I think that when you look at the symmetry, if you will, of coal prices, we think at $175, we have a reasonable planning assumption for 2012. Obviously, we won't know that until we get later into 2011, but based upon what I know, it feels like a pretty reasonable assumption for us to make.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would have to agree with that. Thank you. That's a great observation. If I could move on to another market question related to oil markets, perhaps for Lynn, the Brent premium and then, could you talk about what that means for you and what your per
componenttext: Yes, I would have to agree with that. Thank you. That's a great observation. If I could move on to another market question related to oil markets, perhaps for Lynn, the Brent premium and then, could you talk about what that means for you and what your perspective is on the Brent premium to WTI obviously?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yeah, obviously, Paul, the widening is, you know, not advantageous for us, given it will essentially all over Northeast crudes are priced off of Brent. You know, I'm not going to speculate on whether that is a permanent thing or a cyclical thing. We've se
componenttext:
Yeah, obviously, Paul, the widening is, you know, not advantageous for us, given it will essentially all over Northeast crudes are priced off of Brent. You know, I'm not going to speculate on whether that is a permanent thing or a cyclical thing. We've seen it change. We do know some of the factors that are contributing to it now in that some of the North Sea production is shut in, and we know that there is very strong demand for crude and, you know, Asia-Pacific, with Cushing having a bit of a bottleneck.
So I think I would just leave it at that, that, you know, it's -- it is not a good position for us right now, do not know whether it will be structural.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Thanks. Just to continue on the asking the final question then, if I could, you do sound frustrated and equally determined to source out the operational problems that you've had. Could you just expand a little bit on what was going wrong and, again, how cyclical it was or ultimately whether or not you may get to the point where you shot more refining and released some of that inventory value that you mentioned in the prepared comments. Thanks.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, starting with some of the issues that we had going back into the fourth quarter of last year, we sequentially took down two desalters at the Philadelphia refinery in order to repair them and repair large amounts of sludge that were making them
componenttext:
Okay. Well, starting with some of the issues that we had going back into the fourth quarter of last year, we sequentially took down two desalters at the Philadelphia refinery in order to repair them and repair large amounts of sludge that were making them inoperable and causing us to have environmental exceedances.
And so we went ahead and took the opportunity to deal with that problem. We should get some added benefits from that. But first of all, in the fixes, weve done, we also modify calcium removal system that should prevent us from running into the same problem going forward and that was happening mostly as a result of the (inaudible) that we had been running there.
When we get a little bit of a silver lining here, that in addition to fewer environmental exceedances, we would expect to see about a 6000-barrel a day improvement in our ability to crack (inaudible) cat cracker in 2011 relative to 2010. If I go, then, into sort of late December and into the first quarter, we had problems at Philadelphia due to a leak in an overhead crude line that we feel we need to shut down the unit to do a repair. And so that will be done concurrently with repairing a mechanical issue to a key pressure control valve on the cat cracker at Philadelphia.
And we've been running at reduced rates, both on crude and the cat cracker to deal with both of these issues until we shut down, which we'll do in February and would expect to be back up in March. And then at Marcus Hook, we had an unplanned reformer catalyst regeneration and when we took the reformer down, we had to reduce rates at the cat cracker in order to contain processed stocks. And then we took the opportunity then to bring forward some work that had been planned for later. So the good news is we've got work that would have been done later in the year, planned later in the year out of the way, and all of that worked at Marcus Hook has been completed and all the units are online.
Now, that was answering your question around the liability issues.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It certainly did.
componenttext: It certainly did.

componenttext: Okay. In terms of the second part of your question, which had to do with shutting in process units, I think I would answer this the way that I've answered before, which is we are looking to get the most value for our shareholders out of these assets. And we look continuously at what the options are around that, and right now running them is the best alternative.

componenttext: Good evening. Thanks for taking my question. Lynn, just to follow up on Paul's final question there, from a synergistic standpoint, is there a distinct synergy between the East Coast refinery and the marketing and logistics businesses?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yeah. I think the way that I would put that is that in optimizing the refineries, it is easier to do that the more stable the off takes are, and the off takes tend to be the most stable in our branded retail channel. And so to the extent that we can conti
componenttext:
Yeah. I think the way that I would put that is that in optimizing the refineries, it is easier to do that the more stable the off takes are, and the off takes tend to be the most stable in our branded retail channel. And so to the extent that we can continue to grow the branded retail and use that as a way to pull volume, then we have a much, much better chance of optimizing the hydrocarbon and running in a sense, in a more stable and ratable way which in turn makes it easier to be reliable. So I think that there is a benefit, you know, to having the full change in that regard. You got those refineries and we got to get the most out of them that we possibly can.
I think the other piece of it is, is that to the extent that there are options in the market place for [tourmaline] and pipeline. You know, obviously the more that we can pull volume through our own SXL facilities, the better off that we are. So that essentially the other piece of the equation.

componenttext: Okay. Got it. headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first thing I would say, we're not planning to spend $12 million.
componenttext: Well, first thing I would say, we're not planning to spend $12 million.

componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: But I would say, yes, what you are seeing is you are seeing tremendous growth in India, particularly in India. If you look at their steel consumption per capita, it's at the beginning of the growth curve and that's why you're seeing substantial investment
componenttext:
But I would say, yes, what you are seeing is you are seeing tremendous growth in India, particularly in India. If you look at their steel consumption per capita, it's at the beginning of the growth curve and that's why you're seeing substantial investment of steel companies in India. China continues to grow. I made the point in my comments that I see our entry strategy as likely being alliances and/or ventures, because I think in some of these -- many of these markets, it would be the best approach for us to do it versus simply trying to do wholly owned, building your own battery. I think it's better for us.
There are merchant Coke suppliers in these markets that we can affiliate with. There are new projects being built, and yes, they do pose interesting opportunities for us. But part of the work is, first, what's the right partner, do we have a good, I'll call it energy of skills and abilities in each organization and putting something together to support steel makers that are significantly expanding capacity into emerging markets, it is a very good opportunity.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Okay. Thanks. Understood. And last question, given you guys increased financial flexibility and given some of the assets that have become available in the market on the refining side, would you guys look at some of those assets or are you still focused more on the retail and pipeline side of business?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yeah. We are looking at growing retail, logistics and coke while it is still in the portfolio and its not consistent with our strategy to increase our exposure refining crack. We feel we can get much better returns in the other three businesses.
componenttext: Yeah. We are looking at growing retail, logistics and coke while it is still in the portfolio and its not consistent with our strategy to increase our exposure refining crack. We feel we can get much better returns in the other three businesses.

componenttext: Understood. Thank you for the time.
