headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good evening, and welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call, where we will be discussing the company's fourth quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; Fritz Hender
componenttext:
Thank you, and good evening, and welcome to Sunoco's quarterly conference call, where we will be discussing the company's fourth quarter earnings that we reported this afternoon. With me today are Brian MacDonald, our Chief Financial Officer; Fritz Henderson, who will be the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of SunCoke Energy upon separation; and Clare McGrory, our Manager of Investor Relations. I'll start by making a few introductory comments, and then Brian will address business results and comment on our overall financial position, and Fritz will provide an update on the SunCoke business.
As part of today's call, I'd like to direct you to our website, www.sunocoinc.com, where we have posted a number of presentation slides which may provide a useful reference as we progress through our remarks. I'd also like to refer you to the Safe Harbor statements referenced in Slide #2 of the slide package and is included in this afternoon's earnings release. Now let's begin. 
As you can see from Slides 3 and 4, we earned $13 million in net income excluding special items, or $0.11 per share. When I look at our performance in the fourth quarter, I see three things. First, the marketplace continued to be challenging, the weak demand and excess supply in our markets and the rising crude prices continue to put downward pressure on margins, especially in our Retail business, where it's more difficult to quickly pass through sharper, higher raw material costs. 
On the Refining and Supply side, the northeast region experienced moderate improvement with higher market cracks, but rising crude prices also factored into Refining's results. 
Second, we have additional work to do in the area of operational reliability, which negatively impacted results this quarter when processing units in our Northeast refineries came down for unscheduled maintenance. Overall, our refining utilization for the quarter was 85%, well below our planned rate. Along with improved margin capture, operational liabilities remain a focus area for us this year. 
Third, we continue to make progress in executing our strategy. In Sunoco Logistics Partners, almost $400 million was invested for expansion capital during 2010. Additionally, we've recently announced sale of the Toledo refinery to PBF, which we expect to close in the first quarter, the purchase of 25 high-quality retail sites in upstate New York and new long-term contracts to operate retail locations along New Jersey's Garden State Parkway starting in 2011 and the Ohio Turnpike beginning in 2012. We also continue to be successful in growing our distributor network. 
These various actions are part of a plan that aims for Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in our markets. Despite many challenges in 2010, I'm pleased to say Sunoco made progress against our strategic goal. We finished the year with $1.5 billion in cash, which provides us with considerable strategic flexibility. We also took steps to achieve growth in our retail and logistics businesses and to improve the overall competitiveness of our refineries. 
The work done last year sets the stage for continued progress in 2011. This will only happen if we run our business effectively and in such a way that it can continue to grow even in difficult markets. We cannot count on helping the marketplace. It's our view that conditions in 2011 will be similar to what we saw in 2010. 
Our strategy to use our brand to pull fuel through our system depends on a tightly integrated team that executes well at each step of the value chain. In Retail, we need to grow and protect the strong Sunoco brand that customers have come to know and trust. This entails improving year-on-year sales for fuel and convenience items. By adding more locations and providing a great customer experience at Retail, we expect demand will pull product from our refineries and through the pipelines, terminals and branded retail network. I expect Sunoco Logistics to continue to integrate recent acquisitions while looking for additional growth opportunities inside and outside the traditional Sunoco footprint. 
The recent acquisition of the butane blending business and the reversal and conversion of accrued pipeline to product service are good examples of the range of growth opportunities we're willing to consider. Our refineries sit inside one of the largest transportation fuel markets in the world. If we can operate them safely, reliably and efficiently, we can be competitive in the marketplace. 
Our Refining and Supply segment remains focused on the fundamentals:  improve margin capture, lower our breakeven cost per barrel and operate reliably and safely. 
The other part of our strategy, separating SunCoke Energy from Sunoco and preparing to operate independently, remains a top priority. The recent acquisition of coal assets contiguous to our fuel operation increases our reserves, enables synergies with our existing mines and demonstrates how committed we are to preparing SunCoke for its next phase of growth as an independent entity. 
Fritz will talk about our preparations in more detail shortly, but I am pleased that we have reached a settlement with ArcelorMittal that resolved a lawsuit concerning coke pricing at the Jewell facility, and we now can move forward with the separation of the business to unlock shareholder value. Now I'll turn the call over to Brian.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a pretax income of $121 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in the fourth quarter, which included $123 million pretax of
componenttext:
Thanks, Lynn. First, let me comment on quarterly income attributable to Sunoco shareholders and our special items. We reported a pretax income of $121 million attributable to Sunoco shareholders in the fourth quarter, which included $123 million pretax of net of favorable special items. The special items were primarily associated with gains from the liquidation of crude oil and refined product inventories, a provision for asset write-downs attributable to the Eagle Point refinery and pension settlement losses and accruals for employee terminations and related costs in connection with the ongoing business improvement initiative. 
We also recognize net benefit from taxes related to recurring Coke business tax credits, biofuels tax credits granted at year-end and other adjustments to recurring taxes that occur with changes in estimates. 
We delivered another strong quarter in our Logistics business and achieved our 2010 full year guidance for the Coke business. Market conditions were challenging in our Retail and Refining and Supply business this quarter, and operational issues at our refining facilities prevented us from taking advantage of the moderate sequential improvement that did occur in the northeast market. 
As you can see in Slide 4, Refining and Supply recorded a pretax loss of $17 million. While we are not satisfied in posting a loss in our Refining and Supply business and we are working on the issues around operational reliability, we also can take a step back and recognize our year-over-year improvement in the business. We feel confident that this significant improvement is, to a large degree, the result of actions we have taken, including the closure of the Eagle Point refinery, the focus on reliability and optimization of our plants, refocusing our market strategy and, last but not least, our initiatives around cost structure. 
Our focus on achieving a competitive cost structure continues to yield results. Full year 2010 cash operating expenses excluding fuel, utilities and discontinued operations were approximately $185 million lower than 2009. Excluding the Coke business, where we are adding costs as we grow and prepare for our separation, the improvement versus the prior year is approximately $240 million. This expense measurement basis of cash operating expenses ex fuel and utilities has been used internally to track our progress in reducing our controllable expenses, was also part of our 2010 company-wide bonus targets and demonstrates our efforts and success in driving our costs to a competitive level. 
A year ago, we announced our decision to close the Eagle Point refinery. At that time, we communicated our goal to achieve breakeven cash flow in our Refining and Supply business, even within a tough market environment similar to the one we were experiencing at the time. As a result of the actions we have taken, for the full year 2010, as you can see on Slide 5, we generated positive EBITDA that was in excess of our capital requirements for 2010 in the Refining and Supply business. This represents a tremendous improvement versus 2009, when the business experienced significant cash burn.
So while we continue to be pleased with our progress at many of our controllable aspects of our operations, we will continue to maintain focus on the fundamentals to ensure we are competitive with our assets and can make the most of the market opportunities that do present themselves. 
Regarding Q4 business unit results, I direct you to Slides 4 through 9. First, let's discuss the Retail, Logistics and Coke segments, businesses which we continue to believe have the best prospects for growth. Our Retail Marketing, Logistics and Coke businesses earned $63 million pretax, $47 million after tax, in the aggregate or in the quarter, as detailed on Slides 4 and 6. 
Retail Marketing earned $1 million pretax and $3 million after tax in the fourth quarter of 2010. Retail gasoline margins were significantly challenged as crude prices and wholesale gasoline prices were on the rise throughout most of the quarter. 
While we experienced a challenging quarter, we earned $176 million pretax for the full year 2010, an improvement of $30 million versus the prior year. We do see volatility in this business quarter-to-quarter, but historical annual results prove that over time, this business delivers strong, consistent results. We saw strong volumes relative to the challenging quarter one year ago.  Gasoline and distillate volumes were up by 1.8% and 7%, respectively, on an open both-year basis. Additionally, we made progress during the quarter in our retail growth strategy, including the acquisition of 25 sites in New York, newer extended agreements to operate sites on the Ohio Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and the Palisades Parkway and continued growth in the distributor network. At the end of the fourth quarter, more than 4,900 sites carried the Sunoco flag, and this is the business we continue to target for growth.
Turning now to Logistics, which earned $37 million pretax, $23 million after tax in the fourth quarter. The earnings in this business are almost entirely related to Sunoco's ownership interest in Sunoco Logistics, which continues to be a reliable source of earnings. The throughput and tourmaline business has proven to be a rateable and growing business and is supplemented by crude oil market opportunities when contango market structures exist, as was the case in the third quarter and, to a lesser extent, in the fourth quarter. 
The Logistics business also has strong growth opportunities. Sunoco Logistics spent approximately $390 million in expansion capital during 2010, including both organic and acquisition projects. In 2011, Sunoco Logistics Partners is projecting expansion capital to range from $100 million to $150 million excluding major acquisitions and Project Mariner. 
Coke earned $25 million pretax, $21 million after tax in Q4. The Coke business earned $132 million net income after tax for the full year, consistent with the earnings guidance previously provided. Relative to the third quarter, earnings were lower due to spot sales of coke in the third quarter and higher spending in the fourth quarter related to activities around growth and preparation to be a standalone business. Additionally, production issues at our Indiana Harbor plant and arbitration and legal costs impacted fourth quarter results. At the beginning of the year, we highlighted our expectation that we would be able to achieve breakeven cash flow in the Coke business. We are pleased to report that SunCoke generated EBITDA in excess of capital spending and also generated additional cash flow to working capital in 2010. This is a significant accomplishment for the business to operate as a stand-alone business. 
Regarding the separation, now that the Jewell litigation is behind us, Sunoco intends to move forward with the planned separation of SunCoke in a two-step process. Later in the call, Fritz will address the settlement agreement regarding the Jewell plant, outline earning expectations for 2011 and '12 and provide an update on the growth outlook.
Now turning to Refining and Supply.  As shown on Slide 7, refining and Supply had a loss of $17 million pretax or $8 million after tax in the fourth quarter of 2010, compared to a loss of $227 million pretax or $135 million after tax in the same quarter in 2009. We saw market conditions in the Northeast system improve in the fourth quarter, as reflected in the market margins, but we experienced operational issues which hindered our performance. 
Our systemwide crude unit utilization rate was 85% for the fourth quarter, which is obviously much lower than the optimal rates given the margin environment. The Northeast system was impacted by operational issues, and the Toledo refinery utilization was also negatively impacted by crude oil pipeline allocation limits. 
In the northeast, both refineries experienced mechanical issues late in the quarter for which maintenance work continues into the first quarter of 2011. We expect to complete the maintenance activities in February and return to normal rates in March. As a result of this work, first quarter utilization for the Northeast system is expected to be similar to the fourth quarter of 2010. With respect to our Q4 margin realizations, I refer you to Slides 8 and 9 for more detail on our refining system crude cost and product differentials versus our benchmark. 
As you can see on Slide 8, our systemwide Refining and Supply benchmark averaged $6.11 per barrel for the fourth quarter, and margin capture was 78%. While market margins and market capture rates were both significantly improved from the same quarter of last year, our margin capture was challenged by both rising crude prices and our own operational difficulties. Excluding crude timing, which negatively impacted the capture rate for the second consecutive quarter, margin capture was 86%. Our operational issues resulted in lack of rateability, which also had a negative impact on our margin  capture in the midst of the current volatile price environment. 
Even with the difficulties experienced in the fourth quarter, we showed significant improvement in margin capture for the full year 2010 versus 2009. Our improvements can be attributed to better reliability and a successful strategy, matching operations to market opportunities. The improved reliability and utilization is both in the northeast and Toledo, as we were undergoing turnaround activity in Toledo during late 2009. Overall, as compared to last year, we benefited from higher overall distillate and ULSD production as a percent of total production. Specifically in 2010, 36% of our net production was distillate versus 32% in 2009, with the offset being less production of the cheaper residual fuels. Our actions that supported the improvement include the closure of Eagle Point, adjustments in our crude slates and the operations of the new hydrotreater unit in Philadelphia. Within the distillate pool, we seized opportunities to upgrade more of the distillate to ULSD when it was attractive to do so. Northeast ULSD differentials to heating oil widened by $0.015 a gallon year-over-year. 
In summary, we still feel confident that we are executing on many of the factors within our control, both operational and how we are approaching the market. We have noted that there can be market factors which affect our margin capture rate in any given reporting period. Additionally, we recognize that reliability of our refineries is an essential component to strong performance, and the fourth quarter is a demonstration of this. We will remain focused on the fundamentals, those elements within our control, to drive strong performance in whatever environment exists. 
As previously noted, our first quarter utilization is expected to be similar to the fourth quarter, due to maintenance work in our northeast system. Accordingly, we expect challenged Refining and Supply results again in the first quarter, given the resulting lower utilization level, along with still-rising crude prices and relatively weaker northeast market conditions evident thus far. 
Finally, let me take a few minutes to discuss our financial position at the end of December. In conjunction with that, I'll direct you to Slides 10 and 11. From a funds flow perspective, our fourth quarter net cash flow before debt activity at Sunoco, excluding Sunoco Logistics, was a source of approximately $360 million. We ended the quarter with cash exceeding debt by approximately $180 million, excluding SXL. This represents a swing of $1.4 billion from the prior year end, when the Sunoco parent was carrying $1.2 billion of net debt. The cash increase in the quarter was driven by working capital movements as we liquidated inventories related to our Eagle Point refinery, which was shut down in late 2009. We ended the quarter with a net debt-to-capital ratio of negative 6% at the Sunoco level excluding SXL. 
At December 31, we had $1.5 billion of cash and approximately $1.5 billion of available committed borrowing capacity. As reflected in our balance sheet, our financial position and liquidity continues to be very strong. As seen on Slide 12, our capital spend for 2010, excluding Sunoco Logistics Partners, was $614 million, which included $223 million for Refining and Supply without the gross spending for the Fulton biofuels plant. We were successful in managing capital for this business and reduced our total spend by approximately $75 million versus our guidance at the beginning of the year. This reduction has been achieved primarily due to cost efficiencies in projects as well as some deferred projects which have no impact on safe and reliable operations. We continue to focus on running safe and reliable operations, but we will also continue to limit the discretionary capital that is put into this business. 
As it relates to capital spending expectations for Refining and Supply in 2011, we are currently in discussions with the appropriate government environmental authorities about the requirements of the 2006 Consent Decree as it applies to the Marcus Hook Refinery. As we have previously reported, we have completed projects at the Philadelphia and Toledo refineries under a 2006 Consent Decree. We had expected to make additional capital outlays of approximately $200 million at the Marcus Hook refinery under the same Consent Decree by June 30, 2013. We are hopeful that an outcome of these recent discussions will include an extension of the required timeframe for these capital outlays, thus reducing our capital outlays in 2011 and 2012. This will allow us additional time to explore options that will lower the cost of the total project. If these discussions are successful, and subject to the closing of the Toledo refinery sale, we expect 2011 capital spending in Refining and Supply business to range from $135 million to $145 million, down from 2010 and below DD&A. 
While we are closely managing our capital spend in the Refining and Supply business, we are targeting our Coke, Logistics and Retail businesses for growth opportunities. Our 2011 capital guidance, as shown on Slide 12, includes approximately $165 million to finish the SunCoke Middletown plant, which is expected to be running late in the second half of 2011. We also showed logistics capital spend, including maintenance capital, in the range of $145 million to $195 million, which is expected to be funded by Sunoco Logistics Partners and excludes any potential major acquisitions and Project Mariner spend. 
Lastly, we've continued to pursue growth opportunities in our Retail business. These will be opportunistic and thus are not included in our capital guidance at this time.
As we look forward to 2011, we will continue to take appropriate actions that will assist us in maintaining our financial flexibility, to pursue attractive opportunities in our growth businesses as well as ride out the challenging and volatile refining environment. 
A final balance sheet note related to inventory. At December 31, the current replacement cost of all inventories valued at LIFO exceeds their carrying value by $3.1 billion. Now I'll turn the call over to Fritz Henderson, who will provide an update on the SunCoke business.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good evening. First, as noted in our press release earlier this week, we did reach a settlement with regard to the lawsuit filed by ArcelorMittal concerning our coke pricing from our Jewell facility. The settlement agreement is effective Ja
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good evening. First, as noted in our press release earlier this week, we did reach a settlement with regard to the lawsuit filed by ArcelorMittal concerning our coke pricing from our Jewell facility. The settlement agreement is effective January 1 of this year, 2011, and includes the following terms. First, a renegotiation of the Jewell coke contract, including the elimination of what was called the Jewell coal cost multiplier, and an increase in the fees at Jewell. The pricing of Jewell coal will be based upon the third-party coal price at SunCoke's Haverhill facility. Second, a renegotiation and increase in the fees paid under the Haverhill agreement. Third, the take-or-pay basis of both Jewell and Haverhill agreements with ArcelorMittal will be extended through 2020. This extension provides SunCoke a guaranteed outlet for this coke production through 2020, and both of these contracts were previously structured to convert to the basis of ArcelorMittal's U.S. requirement effective October 2012, so we extended the take-or-pay through 2020. 
Finally, in addition to resolving the Jewell litigation, earlier this week, we also negotiated a settlement of arbitration claims related to our supply of coke to ArcelorMittal from our Indiana Harbor site. Costs associated with the settlement were largely accrued in the fourth quarter. Combined with the Jewell settlement, we have now resolved all of our existing material and commercial disputes with ArcelorMittal, allowing us to focus on building a productive dialogue in partnership with our largest customer, including possible extension of the Indiana Harbor contract that expires in 2013. The Indiana Harbor contract is, to date, the only contract that we have not covered by longer-term take-or-pay arrangements. We're pleased to put these matters behind us, but we continue to move forward with our plans to separate the business and unlock shareholder value.
On the operating side of the business, reflecting both operating and capacity issues at our Indiana Harbor facility, we did not deliver to our contractual minimum to 2010. This was the only facility where we missed our minimums in 2010. As the coke was not required, however, there were no shortfall penalties payable by SunCoke. 
With regard to 2011, while we're aggressively pursuing oven reliability repairs and throughput initiatives, we do not expect to be able to restore volumes to the contractual minimums at Indiana Harbor, and as such, we're working with our customer to identify possible other supply sources while we implement operating improvements in our own facilities. 
Let me take a moment to discuss earnings guidance. Turning to Slide 14. In 2011, SunCoke Energy is expected to earn EBITDA in the range of $165 million to $200 million, based upon our average contracted coal purchase price for 2011 of approximately $165 per ton. As compared to 2010 actual results, earnings in 2011 will be lower due to the revised terms of the Jewell coke contract and higher operating costs related to relocation of the business from Knoxville to Chicago and operation as a standalone company, partially offset by higher coke market prices and higher production related to a full year of Granite City operation and the expected startup of our Middletown operations. 
In 2012, with a full year of Middletown operations and increased coal production from our expansion, we expect EBITDA to range from $280 million to $320 million. This assumes a coal price of approximately $175 per ton. Coal purchases have not yet been contracted for 2012. They wouldn't expect them to be contracted forward until late in 2011, but at $175, these are well below where we see coal prices in the spot markets today. 
The net income guidance shown on the chart flows from the EBITDA levels but does not include any interest expense associated with the yet-to-be-determined capital structure for SunCoke.
As Slide 15 reflects, we continue to work towards preparing SunCoke for successful operation as a standalone entity, including preparing for the relocation of our headquarters to Chicago and hiring key leadership. 
While we prepare for the separation of the SunCoke business, we also continue to actively pursue opportunities for new projects, both in the U.S. and internationally. As we saw once again in the most recent steel downturn, long-term take-or-pay agreements provide a strong measure of stability in our future cash flows, with all of our customers respecting their commitments through this most recent period, for example. Looking forward, beyond the stable base of our existing contracts, we continue to see a number of growth opportunities in both coke and in coal.  Specifically, in the U.S., we're seeing demand for additional coke supply from multiple customers. When combined with our desire to introduce a small amount of merchant capacity into our coke battery fleet, we see an opportunity to build at least one more U.S. coke plant, with the potential to be larger than our traditional coking batteries. And here, I'm referring to our batteries at Haverhill 1 and 2 as well as our Granite City facility. These facilities typically have between 550,000 and 600,000 tons per year capacity. 
In coal, we're expanding capacity in our existing Jewell metallurgical coal mine, increasing production from 1.2 million tons per year to approximately 1.7 million tons per year by the end of 2012 on an annualized basis. We also recently completed the acquisition of Harold Keene Coal, which will take our production to an estimated 2 million tons per year by the end of 2012. Reflected in the elimination of the Jewell multiplier, but also the expansion of our coal production, our price sensitivity to coal is expected to be plus or minus $20 million in pretax earnings for every $10-per-ton movement in coal prices, again on the running rate basis, by the end of 2012.
Internationally, we see opportunity to expand and grow our footprint, most likely through ventures and/or alliances in India, Eastern Europe, Brazil and China, something we are prioritizing in 2011. Let me turn it back to Lynn to close the call.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. So in closing, to deliver value to shareholders, we will continue to execute a strategy that positions Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in our markets. This strategy includes pursuing growth in Retail and Logisti
componenttext: Thanks, Rick. So in closing, to deliver value to shareholders, we will continue to execute a strategy that positions Sunoco to become the premier provider of transportation fuels in our markets. This strategy includes pursuing growth in Retail and Logistics, where potential returns are highest, while continuing to run our manufacturing facilities safely, reliably and efficiently. With that, I'll ask the moderator to open the lines for any questions you may have.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Paul Cheng. [Barclays Capital]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Paul Cheng. [Barclays Capital]

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The number of the -- hopefully a quick question. On the separation, I think previous self-imposed timeline is by the middle of the year. With the lawsuit, there seems like we may have some delay.  So where are we standing in the process?  When will you ex
componenttext: The number of the -- hopefully a quick question. On the separation, I think previous self-imposed timeline is by the middle of the year. With the lawsuit, there seems like we may have some delay.  So where are we standing in the process?  When will you expect the separation going to happen, and when could we expect the Form 10 or the S-1 will be filed?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Paul, I'll answer your question in two parts. First, on the prospective filing. Due to SEC regulations and under the advice of counsel, it would not be appropriate to comment beyond what we've said in the script, namely, that we are proceeding with the se
componenttext: Paul, I'll answer your question in two parts. First, on the prospective filing. Due to SEC regulations and under the advice of counsel, it would not be appropriate to comment beyond what we've said in the script, namely, that we are proceeding with the separation, and the separation will be a two-step process. With regard to your second question around the timing, as we go through the separation process, certain events are under our control and certain events aren't. Part of the separation process will involve going through certain SEC filings and related processes, and those processes, as an example, are not fully in our control. As you noted, we've settled the Arcelor matter, and we're moving forward as expeditiously as possible. And we plan to effect the separation as soon as practicable, and clearly, we would like to get the step, first step of the separation done as soon as possible.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have two questions, if I could. Could you discuss the capital structure of SunCoke, or will we see that in the S-1? And with any incremental cash upstream to Sun from SunCoke leverage, and I appreciate if you can't give a number now for the reasons that
componenttext: I have two questions, if I could. Could you discuss the capital structure of SunCoke, or will we see that in the S-1? And with any incremental cash upstream to Sun from SunCoke leverage, and I appreciate if you can't give a number now for the reasons that you just discussed, plus your current high and growing cash position. Plus Eagle Point inventories, I presume, are another incremental $100 million. Do you see growth opportunities in that size for Sun parent, which is somewhere north of $2 billion?  Or what are your views on potentially returning capital to shareholders? And I have a follow-up, please.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. So on the first question around capital structure. As I'm sure you've picked up from Paul, we won't really have much more to say on this call. With regard to the cash, clearly the balance sheet's in a pretty good position and has dramatically
componenttext: Sure, Evan. So on the first question around capital structure. As I'm sure you've picked up from Paul, we won't really have much more to say on this call. With regard to the cash, clearly the balance sheet's in a pretty good position and has dramatically improved from where it was a year ago. That said, the refining environment continues to be challenging, and so the cash balance gives us flexibility there. We continue to want to grow in SXL and Retail and see some uses of the cash to grow those businesses. And then we also see some debt reduction, as we've talked about in the past. And lastly, with this amount of cash, we have a lot of strategic flexibility and optionality.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It does include Harold Keene Coal volumes in 2012, and we'd be about three-quarters of the way through, at least three-quarters of the way through our expansion in 2012 volume.  So we wouldn't be at the full 2 million in 2012 for the full year, but we'll
componenttext: It does include Harold Keene Coal volumes in 2012, and we'd be about three-quarters of the way through, at least three-quarters of the way through our expansion in 2012 volume.  So we wouldn't be at the full 2 million in 2012 for the full year, but we'll be well on our way to that number for the full year. And, as I said, it does include Harold Keene.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned a potential new contract with a U.S. partner for coke battery. Is that something that you expect to see in 2011?
componenttext: You mentioned a potential new contract with a U.S. partner for coke battery. Is that something that you expect to see in 2011?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a priority for us. I would say we need to finalize with the customers what their demands are. As I said in my comments, we also would like to introduce some element of merchant capacity into our coke battery fleet, and we need to go through the
componenttext: Well, it's a priority for us. I would say we need to finalize with the customers what their demands are. As I said in my comments, we also would like to introduce some element of merchant capacity into our coke battery fleet, and we need to go through the permitting process, and we're evaluating all of that as we speak. As to whether or not we could have something to announce in 2011, I clearly can't say, because we need to finalize a lot of different things. But there are -- the signs are encouraging, is the way I would put it for at least one more plant in the U.S., and this would be much larger than what our traditional plants are.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttextpreview: I just want to try to understand the coke guidance a little better, if I may. Sorry, Fritz, to belabor this point, but -- so basically, the previous guidance, obviously, has come down to the $60 million guidance impact from the settlement. But if I look a
componenttext: I just want to try to understand the coke guidance a little better, if I may. Sorry, Fritz, to belabor this point, but -- so basically, the previous guidance, obviously, has come down to the $60 million guidance impact from the settlement. But if I look at the sensitivity you'd given us previously on the -- the fact that you've gone from a $125 to a $175 coal assumption, it looks like something else has changed there, because net-net, the EBITDA looks like it's a little bit light. Can you kind of walk us through those moving parts? And I also have a follow-up, please.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's two issues -- it's actually three, two of which are the most significant. One is, we have built -- the prior guidance didn't include standalone costs in the forecast. This forecast does include all the standalone costs associated with running
componenttext: Yes. There's two issues -- it's actually three, two of which are the most significant. One is, we have built -- the prior guidance didn't include standalone costs in the forecast. This forecast does include all the standalone costs associated with running the business separately. The second piece is we have seen increases in coal production costs, which we had built into this revised guidance. So you're right in saying the restructured Arcelor contract is unfavorable relative to prior guidance. Higher coal prices is favorable, but the two pieces you're missing are, one, we needed to update and we did update the coal production costs, and second, we built in all the standalone costs associated with running the business publicly.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Sankey of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow up from Doug, and just ask you to talk a little bit about the strength in price, coal prices we're seeing right now. And just remind us of how high they are, if you would, how sustainable you think that is. And then, further to what Doug
componenttext: Can I just follow up from Doug, and just ask you to talk a little bit about the strength in price, coal prices we're seeing right now. And just remind us of how high they are, if you would, how sustainable you think that is. And then, further to what Doug was saying, could you also indicate to us the sensitivity of the EBITDA and earnings to dollar changes in the coke price?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, I'll answer the second question first. We talked about, when I went through the presentation -- basically, when you look at the sensitivity to coal prices, once you get to 2 million tons, the sensitivity is 2 million x $10. So it's plus o
componenttext: Well, as I said, I'll answer the second question first. We talked about, when I went through the presentation -- basically, when you look at the sensitivity to coal prices, once you get to 2 million tons, the sensitivity is 2 million x $10. So it's plus or minus $20 million of pretax profit for every $10 movement in the price of coal. Because you would hold, at that point, your production cost constant, and all you're doing is guaranteeing the price. So your first question on where coal prices are today. First of all, not a lot of trading in the spot market. The primary source of spot coal, met coal, in the world is Australia, and Australia's being hit by both the flood impact as well as now the cyclone impact. If you had to go out and purchase spot met coal today, it's -- in our best judgment, it's well above $200 a ton today. And it's really not readily available, given what's happened. Most coal is contracted for on a long-term basis, though. But it's pretty clear [indiscernible] a lot that -- the combination of continued demand growth in China, continued demand growth in India for met coal, combined with a reasonable outlook in the U.S and in Brazil -- I mean, I think that when you look at the symmetry, if you will, of coal prices, we think at $175, we have a reasonable planning assumption for 2012. Obviously, we won't know that until we get later into 2012, but based upon what I know, it feels like a pretty reasonable assumption for us to make.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: If I can move onto another market question related to oil markets. The Brent premium, then. Can you just talk a little bit about what that means to you and what you're expecting on it, the Brent premium to WTI, obviously.
componenttext: If I can move onto another market question related to oil markets. The Brent premium, then. Can you just talk a little bit about what that means to you and what you're expecting on it, the Brent premium to WTI, obviously.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, Paul.  But the widening is not advantageous for us, given that essentially all of our northeast crews are priced off of Brent. I'm not going to speculate on whether that is a permanent thing or a cyclical thing. We've seen it change. We do
componenttext: Yes, obviously, Paul.  But the widening is not advantageous for us, given that essentially all of our northeast crews are priced off of Brent. I'm not going to speculate on whether that is a permanent thing or a cyclical thing. We've seen it change. We do know some of the factors that are contributing to it now in that some of the North Sea production is shut-in. And we know that there is very strong demand for crude in Asia-Pacific, with Cushing having a bit of a bottleneck. So I think I'd just leave it at that, that it is not a good position for us right now. We do not know whether it will be structural.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to continue on asking a final question then, if I could. You do sound frustrated and equally determined to sort out the operational problems that you've had. Could you just expand a little bit on what was going wrong and, again, how cyclical it was,
componenttext: Just to continue on asking a final question then, if I could. You do sound frustrated and equally determined to sort out the operational problems that you've had. Could you just expand a little bit on what was going wrong and, again, how cyclical it was, or ultimately whether or not you may get to the point where you shut more refining and release some of that inventory value that you mentioned in the prepared comments?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, starting with some of the issues that we had going back into the fourth quarter of last year, we sequentially took down two desalters at the Philadelphia refinery in order to repair them and remove large amounts of sludge that were making them inope
componenttext: Okay, starting with some of the issues that we had going back into the fourth quarter of last year, we sequentially took down two desalters at the Philadelphia refinery in order to repair them and remove large amounts of sludge that were making them inoperable and causing us to have environmental exceedances. And so we went ahead and took the opportunity to deal with that problem. We should get some added benefit from that -- well, first of all, in the fixes we've done, we also modified a calcium removal system that should prevent us from running into the same problem going forward, and that was happening mostly as a result of the Doba that we had been running there. And we get a little bit of a silver lining here in that in addition to fewer environmental exceedances, we would expect to see about a 6,000-barrel-a-day improvement in our ability to crack resid at the cat cracker in 2011 relative to 2010. If I go, then, into sort of late December and into the first quarter, we had problems at Philadelphia due to a leak in an overhead crude line that we feel we need to shut down the unit to do a repair. And so that will be done concurrently with repairing a mechanical issue to a key pressure control valve on the cat cracker at Philadelphia. And we've been running at reduced rates, both on the crude and the cat cracker, to deal with both of these issues until we shut down, which we'd do in February and would expect to be back up in March. And then at Marcus Hook, we had an unplanned reformer catalyst regeneration, and when we took the reformer down, we had to reduce rates at the cat cracker in order to contain process stocks. And we took the opportunity then to bring forward some work that had been planned for later, so the good news is that we've got some work that would would've been done later in the year, planned for later in the year, out of the way. And all of that work at Marcus Hook has been completed, and all the units are online. Now that was answering your question around the liability issues.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You certainly did.
componenttext: You certainly did.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: In terms of your second part of your question, which has to do with shutting-in process units, I think I'd answer this the way that I'd answered before, which is we're looking to get the most value for our shareholders out of these assets, and we look continuously at what the options are around that, and right now, running them is the best alternative.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Lynn, just a follow-up on Paul's final question there. From a synergistic standpoint, is there a distinct synergy between the East Coast refinery and the Marketing and Logistics businesses?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the way that I would put that is that in optimizing the refineries, it is easier to do that the more stable the offtakes are. And the offtakes tend to be the most stable in our branded Retail channel. And so to the extent that we can continue to g
componenttext: I think the way that I would put that is that in optimizing the refineries, it is easier to do that the more stable the offtakes are. And the offtakes tend to be the most stable in our branded Retail channel. And so to the extent that we can continue to grow the branded retail and use that as a way to pull volume, then we have a much, much better chance of optimizing the hydrocarbon and running, in a sense, in a more stable and ratable way, which, in turn, makes it easier to be reliable. So I think that there is a benefit to having the full chain in that regard. If you've got those refineries, then we've got to get the most out of them that we possibly can. I think the other piece of it is, is that to the extent that there are options in the marketplace for tourmaline in a pipeline, obviously the more that we can pull volume through our own SXL facility, the better off that we are. So that's essentially the other piece of the equation.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just so I understand the potential international opportunities. I guess when we hear in the press that POSCO is going to build a $12 billion steel plant in India, is that kind of an opportunity for you guys to add your services to that sort of plant?
componenttext: And just so I understand the potential international opportunities. I guess when we hear in the press that POSCO is going to build a $12 billion steel plant in India, is that kind of an opportunity for you guys to add your services to that sort of plant?  Or is that something different?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, first thing I would say is we're not planning to spend $12 billion.  But I would say, yes, what you are seeing is you're seeing tremendous growth in India. Particularly in India, because if you look at their steel consumption per capita, it's at the
componenttext: Well, first thing I would say is we're not planning to spend $12 billion.  But I would say, yes, what you are seeing is you're seeing tremendous growth in India. Particularly in India, because if you look at their steel consumption per capita, it's at the beginning of the growth curve, and that's why you're seeing substantial investment of steel companies in India. China continues to grow. I made the point in my comments that I'd see our entry strategy as likely being alliances and/or ventures, because I think in many of these markets, it would be the best approach for us to do it versus simply trying to do a wholly-owned, building our own battery. I think it's better for us. There are merchant coke suppliers in these markets that we could affiliate with. There are new projects being built, and, yes, they do pose interesting opportunities for us. But part of the work is, first, what's the right partner? Do we have a good, I'll call it, synergy of the skills and abilities in each organization? And putting something together to support steelmakers that are significantly expanding capacity in these emerging markets, it is a very good opportunity.

componenttext: We're looking at growing Retail, Logistics and Coke while it is still in the portfolio. And it's not consistent with our strategy to increase our exposure refining crack. We feel we can get much better returns in the other three businesses.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Back on the fourth quarter results in coke. First, can you talk a little bit about the coke volume decline 3Q to 4Q? Was that all due to this Indiana Harbor issue? And maybe you can expand on exactly what the problem is at that plant?
componenttext: Back on the fourth quarter results in coke. First, can you talk a little bit about the coke volume decline 3Q to 4Q? Was that all due to this Indiana Harbor issue? And maybe you can expand on exactly what the problem is at that plant?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was largely driven by the Indiana Harbor underproduction. Part of it was weather, but most of it was the impact of the facility itself. The production issues -- this is not our oldest plant, it's our second-oldest plant. And we've had production i
componenttext: Yes, it was largely driven by the Indiana Harbor underproduction. Part of it was weather, but most of it was the impact of the facility itself. The production issues -- this is not our oldest plant, it's our second-oldest plant. And we've had production issues in the past, but they became more serious.  We had more ovens out of service, and we kicked off in the quarter, actually, a pretty aggressive oven maintenance and repair process which will continue into 2011 to try to get ourself back closer to the minimum. But there was certainly the impact of lower production at Indiana Harbor in the fourth quarter. Secondly, we did have some spot sales in the third quarter, actually. So third quarter is a little higher just due to spot sales.  But Indiana Harbor remains probably -- not probably.  It is our most significant operating issue in 2011 in terms of improving throughput.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You seem to indicate that it's going to be an issue ongoing here in the first quarter. When do you think the maintenance gets everything cleared up on the volumes?
componenttext: You seem to indicate that it's going to be an issue ongoing here in the first quarter. When do you think the maintenance gets everything cleared up on the volumes?

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's an issue for 2011. I think what we're doing is we were doing work aggressively. As we've come into this year, we were actually making the some progress in January till the last week. Snow had gotten in the way. But we're going to take that back
componenttext: Well, it's an issue for 2011. I think what we're doing is we were doing work aggressively. As we've come into this year, we were actually making the some progress in January till the last week. Snow had gotten in the way. But we're going to take that back up next week when we get the asset back up to full utilization. I do think this is a problem that we're going to be wrestling with in the first quarter and maybe even in the first half. Because this is an asset that has some significant structural issues we need to address. We know what we need to do. We're working with our customer, they know what the issues are, as we try to bring our production back up to at least its contractual minimum.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttextpreview: High-vol met coal A, by and large. As opposed to our traditional Jewell met coal, which is mid-vol, it's higher volatility, it's very good coal for blending. It needs to be blended with other coals. It is met coal, and we actually like its properties in t
componenttext: High-vol met coal A, by and large. As opposed to our traditional Jewell met coal, which is mid-vol, it's higher volatility, it's very good coal for blending. It needs to be blended with other coals. It is met coal, and we actually like its properties in terms of being able to blend with other coals.

componenttext: I wouldn't say that. They have, frankly, some more high-wall mining than our mines, which are deep and narrow scene. So I wouldn't say that Harold Keene is higher, it's lower, it's higher cost -- certainly where they're doing deeper scenes, I would say it's comparable.  But they do have more high-wall mining, which would be lower cost.

componenttext: No, Chi, it's Brian. There's nothing really going on there other than kind of the run-up in crude, which squeezed the margins. And as we've said before, this business can sort of bounce around a little bit quarter-to-quarter, but when you look at it over a rolling four quarter period or annual period, it's a pretty consistent and ratable business.

headline: Sunoco, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Brian here. A couple of things. I think, clearly, the cash generation today is a lot better than it's been, but it's not particularly exciting. That said, we're working on a number of things to reduce cost, capture more margin, bring down the c
componenttext: Mark, it's Brian here. A couple of things. I think, clearly, the cash generation today is a lot better than it's been, but it's not particularly exciting. That said, we're working on a number of things to reduce cost, capture more margin, bring down the capital, run the assets better and, therefore, by definition, generate more cash as we go through the cycle. As you think about the inventory, don't forget to do the math on the associated taxes as well as the other side of the balance sheet, which is the payable side of those inventories. So make sure you kind of look on both sides of the balance sheet and you think through some of the tax consequences there. And we are well aware of those numbers and calculations, and we're focused on getting the refineries running better and throwing out more cash. And I think last year, we made a step function improvement, and we've got more work to do.

componenttext: I guess what I'd say is that we already have a lot of toll business, and the toll business that we're going into is going to be relatively similar to the toll business we've had before. And then about 75-ish, I think, distributor locations, and we would expect them to perform very similarly to the other rest of the distributor collective trade.
